column1: What kind of samples do you think the real Mars robot takes for analysis?
Why does it sometimes take longer for information from Mars robots to reach Mission Control on Earth?
column2: Both Earth & Mars have elliptical orbits, so are not always the same distance apart.

column1: Approximately how many photos are combined to make the panoramas we currently have of the Martian landscape?
column2: As few as 400 images and as many as 900. The panorama below is a combination of 817 photos taken by the Mars Exploration Rover Opportunity.

column1: Suggest an advantage of taking multiple samples as the robot travels.
column2: It increases efficiency, allowing the terrain to be mapped more rapidly and avoids missing valuable data.

column1: How do you think scientists use the data collected to identify areas for further exploration?
column2: They will look at patterns and distribution of variables measured and compare them with earlier data or other locations and related them to their initial hypothesis.

column1: Please tell us one thing you liked about the day, one way we could we make it better and one thing you learnt.
